Description: THE OVERALL AIM OF THIS PROPOSED WORK IS TO ADDRESS THE INFORMATION NEEDS OF LAND MANAGERS BY QUANTIFING THE EFFECTS OF TERRAIN, FIRE SEVERITY (AS MEASURED BY CANOPY MORTALITY), AND SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ON THE POST-FIRE REGENERATION OF VEGETATION IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS OF WASHINGTON STATE. I WILL DO THIS BY ADDRESSING THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS: 1) TO WHAT EXTENT CAN FOREST RECOVERY AND GROWTH ACROSS THE WA BLUE MOUNTAINS BE BETTER QUANTIFIED THROUGH THE INCLUSION OF NAIP DAP DATA IN AN EXISTING LANDSAT-BASED MODEL  2) WHAT EFFECT DO PRE- AND POST-FIRE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS (INCLUDING TIMBER HARVEST, THINNING, SALVAGE LOGGING AND PLANTING) HAVE ON THE POST-FIRE REGENERATION OF VEGETATION IN THE WA BLUE MOUNTAINS THIS RESEARCH WILL FURTHER THE EXISTING LITERATURE ON QUANTIFYING POST-FIRE FOREST RECOVERY VIA TIME SERIES ANALYSIS OF MULTISPECTRAL IMAGERY BY COMBINING AN INVESTIGATION OF LONGERTERM REGENERATION (UP TO 15  YEARS POST-FIRE) WITH FIELD DATA, REPEAT MEASUREMENTS OF VEGETATION HEIGHT FROM AERIAL PHOTOGRAMMETRY, AND RECORDS OF PAST MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THIS ANALYSIS IS OF DIRECT RELEVANCE TO MANAGERS OF FOREST LAND SEEKING TO INCORPORATE VEGETATION RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE INTO THEIR DECISION MAKING, EITHER PROACTIVELY, OR IN RESPONSE TO A RECENT FIRE EVENT. RELEVANT INFORMATION WILL BE PROVIDED TO MANAGERS AS A WRITTEN REPORT AND THROUGH A PRESENTATION TO A GROUP OF LOCAL LAND MANAGERS.

PROBLEM STATEMENT.POST-WILDFIRE DEBRIS FLOWS POSE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO DOWNSTREAM COMMUNITIES IN THE YEARS FOLLOWING WILDFIRE. TO MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF POST-WILDFIRE DEBRIS FLOWS, CURRENT HAZARD ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORKS PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF DEBRIS-FLOW LIKELIHOOD AND VOLUME. HOWEVER, FEW HAZARD ASSESSMENTS INCLUDE ESTIMATES OF POST-WILDFIRE DEBRIS-FLOW RUNOUT, PRIMARILY DUE TO THE HISTORIC LACK OF A RAPID AND ACCURATE DEBRIS-FLOW RUNOUT MODEL THAT HAS BEEN TESTED EXTENSIVELY IN POST-WILDFIRE SCENARIOS. THIS LIMITS OUR ABILITY TO PREDICT AND MITIGATE THE DOWNSTREAM IMPACTS OF POST-WILDFIRE DEBRIS FLOWS AND TO ASSESS HOW PRE-FIRE FUEL MANAGEMENT TREATMENTS INFLUENCE DEBRIS-FLOW RUNOUT. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THIS GAP IN KNOWLEDGE BY TRANSITIONING PRODF, A RECENTLY DEVELOPED DEBRIS-FLOW RUNOUT MODEL, FROM A RESEARCH GRADE TOOL TO ONE THAT CAN BE USED BY DECISION MAKERS AND IMPLEMENTED INTO EXISTING PRE-FIRE HAZARD ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORKS.OBJECTIVES.PRODF IS CURRENTLY LIMITED AS A TOOL IN PRE-FIRE SCENARIOS BECAUSE IT REQUIRES TWO FLOW MOBILITY PARAMETERS THAT MUST BE CALIBRATED TO A PREVIOUS EVENT AT EVERY NEW SITE. ONE OF THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROVIDE CONSTRAINTS ON THE TYPICAL RANGE OF FLOW MOBILITY PARAMETERS BY CALIBRATING THE MODEL AT 20 SITES THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. WE WILL FURTHER TEST THE HYPOTHESIS THAT FLOW MOBILITY PARAMETERS ARE FUNCTIONS OF DEBRIS-FLOW VOLUME AND OR SOIL CLAY CONTENT. ANOTHER OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK WITH THE CALIFORNIA GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (CGS) TO IMPLEMENT PRODF WITHIN AN EXISTING PRE-FIRE HAZARD ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK. THIS WILL ALLOW US TO IDENTIFY WHICH WATERSHEDS POSE THE GREATEST THREAT TO DOWNSTREAM COMMUNITIES AND ASSESS HOW PRE-FIRE FUEL MANAGEMENT TREATMENTS INFLUENCE POST-WILDFIRE DEBRIS-FLOW RUNOUT.BENEFITS.THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF PRODF SO THAT IT CAN BE USED AS A TOOL IN PRE-FIRE SCENARIOS. WE WILL PRESENT RESULTS TO DECISION MAKERS AT THE 10TH INTERNATIONAL FIRE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT CONGRESS IN DECEMBER 2023. ADDITIONALLY, SI GORR WILL TRAVEL TO REDDING, CALIFORNIA TO MEET WITH SCIENTISTS AT CGS TO ENSURE THAT PRODF IS INTEGRATED INTO THEIR PRE-FIRE HAZARD ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK IN SUCH A WAY THAT IT IS EASY TO IMPLEMENT MOVING FORWARD. WE WILL ALSO UPDATE THE CURRENT PRODF REPOSITORY WITH ADDITIONAL GUIDANCE BASED ON RESULTS OF THIS STUDY.

CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECTIONS FOR THE NORTHEASTERN U.S. (NE US), COUPLED WITH RECENT DROUGHT AND WILDFIRES (U.S. DROUGHT MONITOR, 2022  NECC 2022), HAVE RAISED CONCERNS ABOUT HOW INCREASING TEMPERATURES AND VARIABLE PRECIPITATION MAY COMPLICATE FUELS AND FIRE MANAGEMENT IN THIS CHANGING FIRE ENVIRONMENT (NATIONAL CLIMATE ASSESSMENT, 2018). IN THIS PROPOSED STUDY, SI BREIGENZER WILL EXPAND HIS THESIS WORK TO RESPOND TO THE NEEDS OF THIS FUNDING ANNOUNCEMENT AND THE NATIONAL WILDLAND FIRE CRISIS STRATEGY BY CREATING A MICROCLIMATE-BASED FIRE MANAGEMENT DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT COMBINES THE LATEST FOREST MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES WITH THE CURRENT NEEDS OF FIRE MANAGERS IN THE NE US. HE WILL USE NEW ESTIMATES OF VEGETATION STRUCTURE (TERRESTRIAL LIDAR) AND FUEL MOISTURE TO LINK FOREST STRUCTURE, MICROCLIMATE, AND FUEL MOISTURE AT MANAGEMENT-RELEVANT SCALES. THIS RESEARCH DIRECTLY FILLS KNOWLEDGE GAPS IDENTIFIED BY FIRE MANAGERS IN REGIONAL WORKSHOPS THAT ARE GUIDING THE EXECUTION OF THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW. FILLING THESE GAPS WILL ENHANCE FIRE MANAGERS  ABILITY TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT SAFE FUEL TREATMENTS FOR HAZARD REDUCTION AND ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS. TO ADDRESS THIS NEED, SI BREIGENZER HAS ASSEMBLED A TEAM OF SCIENTISTS AND FIRE MANAGERS WITH EXPERTISE IN FOREST STRUCTURE AND MICROCLIMATE (PI WASON), FOREST MANAGEMENT (CO-PI KENEFIC), CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS ON THE FIRE ENVIRONMENT (CO-PI LANE), FUEL STRUCTURE AND FIRE BEHAVIOR (CO-PI GALLAGHER), FIRE FUELS MANAGEMENT AND OPERATIONS (CO-PI NEELY), AND SEVEN COOPERATORS THAT COLLECTIVELY MANAGE OVER A MILLION ACRES IN THE NE US AND SUPPORT THIS RESEARCH.

PROBLEM STATEMENT: PRESCRIBED FIRES IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES ARE PLANNED AROUND WEATHER AND SITE CONDITIONS (RYAN ET AL., 2013). OF PARTICULAR IMPORTANCE IS FUEL MOISTURE, WHICH INFLUENCES THE RATE OF FUELS CONSUMPTION, FIRE FRONT INTENSITY AND RATE OF SPREAD, AND POST-FIRE SURVIVAL (RYAN ET AL., 2013). IN MANY PRESCRIBED BURNS, MANAGERS ATTEMPT TO REDUCE SURFACE FUELS, AND CAUSE MORTALITY ACROSS A GRADIENT OF TREES SIZES (NPS, NWCG). WHILE MOST MORTALITY GOALS TARGET SMALLER TREE SIZE CLASSES, IT IS COMMON FOR OBJECTIVES TO INCLUDE THE CREATION OF CROWN OPENINGS IN THE CANOPY BY KILLING PATCHES OF LARGER SIZE TREES. ACHIEVING TREE MORTALITY IS HIGHLY INFLUENCED BY A TREES FOLIAR MOISTURE CONTENT (FMC). MAPS OF TREE-LEVEL FMC WOULD ALLOW MANAGERS TO EITHER TARGET THINNING OF MOISTURE-STRESS TREES OR BETTER PRESCRIBE IGNITION PATTERNS TO ACHIEVE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES (I.E., DECREASE FOREST DENSITY, REDUCE FUEL CONNECTIVITY).UNFORTUNATELY, CURRENT MODELS OF PLANT MOISTURE WERE DEVELOPED FOR COARSE SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS (10-30 M RESOLUTION), LIMITING THEIR USE IN PRESCRIPTION PLANNING (GAO, 1996). HOWEVER, RECENT ADVANCES IN UNMANNED AERIAL SYSTEM (UAS) IMAGING MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO HAVE COMPARABLE DATA AT  10 CM RESOLUTION. SIMILAR UAS DATA HAS BEEN USED IN AGRICULTURE TO ASSESS PLANT DROUGHT-CONDITIONS TO INFORM PRECISION IRRIGATION (EZENNE ET AL., 2019). HOWEVER, NO COMPREHENSIVE MODELS OF TREE-LEVEL FMC HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED.SINCE KNOWLEDGE OF PRE-FIRE FUEL CONDITIONS ARE LIMITED, THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING A RAPID ASSESSMENT SYSTEM OF TREE-LEVEL FMC THAT CAN BE SHARED WITH MANAGERS. THIS RAPID ASSESSMENT SYSTEM WILL BUILD ON LABORATORY-DEVELOPED PREDICTIVE MODELS OF FMC OF GREENHOUSE-GROWN SAPLINGS BUT HAS YET TO BE SCALED FOR TESTING IN MATURE FORESTS (LAD ET AL., IN PREP). THUS, THIS PROJECT WILL TEST THE SCALABILITY OF THE LABORATORY-DEVELOPED PREDICTIVE MODELS TO NATURAL FOREST CONDITIONS.OBJECTIVES: THIS RESEARCH WILL ADDRESS THE QUESTION: CAN EXISTING PREDICTIVE MODELS OF FOLIAR MOISTURE CONTENT ACCURATELY PREDICT FMC OF INDIVIDUAL TREES USING UAS DATA  WE HAVE DESIGNED A FIELD CAMPAIGN TO TEST THE DEPLOYMENT OF LABORATORY MODELS OF FMC TO MIXED-CONIFER AND PONDEROSA PINE-DOMINANT FORESTS. SUCCESSFUL FIELD TESTING WILL PROVIDE MANAGERS WITH A RAPID TOOL TO MAP INDIVIDUAL TREE FMC, ENABLING TARGETED THINNING OF DROUGHT-STRESSED TREES OR REFINEMENT OF PRESCRIBED FIRE IGNITION PATTERNS TO ACHIEVE OBJECTIVES. I WILL ACHIEVE THIS THOUGH MODEL ACCURACY ASSESSMENTS WHICH WILL BE PRESENTED IN A REPORT TO JFSP, AT A CONFERENCE, AND IN A PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION. SUCCESSFUL MODELS WILL BE SHARED WITH PRESCRIBED FIRE MANAGERS, INCLUDING A TUTORIAL ON HOW TO PROCESS AND USE UAS DATA AS MODEL INPUTS.BENEFITS AND PRODUCTS: OUR STUDY INVOLVES THE TESTING OF NOVEL PREDICTIVE MODELS OF FMC THAT CAN BE USED BY LAND MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS TO ESTIMATE FMC AT THE INDIVIDUAL TREELEVEL. THUS, WE WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL KNOWLEDGE OF SITE CONDITIONS PRIOR TO FOREST TREATMENTS. THESE MODELS WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY A WRITTEN TUTORIAL DESCRIBING THE PROCESSING STEPS REQUIRED TO PREPARE UAS DATA AS THE PREDICTIVE INPUTS TO THE MODEL. WE HOPE TO PROVIDE LAND MANAGERS WITH THIS WRITTEN TUTORIAL AND NOVEL MODELS SO THEY CAN CONDUCT SITE SURVEYS PRIOR TO PRESCRIBED BURNS AND INFORM THEMSELVES OF TREES OR TREEGROUPINGS THAT ARE AT-RISK FOR MORTALITY IN LOW-MODERATE INTENSITY FIRES.

RESEARCH PERTAINING TO THE EFFECTS OF WILDFIRE ON FOREST-ASSOCIATED INSECT COMMUNITIES HAVE LARGELY IGNORED THE RESPONSES OF INSECT PREDATORS TO THESE COMMON DISTURBANCES IN THE WESTERN US, DESPITE THE ECOLOGICAL SERVICES THEY PROVIDE. FOR EXAMPLE, SOCIAL YELLOWJACKET WASPS (HYMENOPTERA:VESPIDAE,VESPINAE) ARE CONSIDERED UBIQUITOUS INSECT PREDATORS IN TEMPERATE FORESTS AND HELP PROVIDE TOP-DOWN REGULATION OF LOWER-TROPHIC ARTHROPOD POPULATIONS, MANY OF WHICH ARE FOREST PESTS. ALTERNATELY, AS YELLOWJACKET VENOM IS PAINFUL (AND POTENTIALLY LETHAL) TOWARDS HUMANS, THEIR PRESENCE CAN IMPEDE MANAGEMENT AND RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, ESPECIALLY IN HIGH-VISITATION AREAS SUCH AS NATIONAL AND STATE PARKS. DESPITE THIS DICHOTOMY, INFORMATION IS LIMITED REGARDING WHAT LANDSCAPE AND STAND-LEVEL FACTORS REGULATE POPULATION LEVELS AND COMMUNITY ASSEMBLAGES OF YELLOWJACKETS FOR THE MAJORITY OF FOREST COVER TYPES REPRESENTATIVE OF THE WESTERN US. WE PROPOSE TO DETERMINE PATTERNS OF YELLOWJACKET COMMUNITY RESPONSE FOLLOWING RECENTLY OCCURRING WILDFIRES IN THE CENTRAL CALIFORNIAN SIERRA NEVADA AND FURTHER DESCRIBE HOW VARIATION IN FOREST HABITAT STRUCTURE INFLUENCE THESE PATTERNS.

THE OVERARCHING PURPOSE OF THE NWFSC IS TO FOSTER SCIENTIST-MANAGER COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATIONTHAT INTEGRATES RELEVANT SCIENCE INTO FIRE AND FUELS MANAGEMENT. WE SEEK MEASURABLE OUTCOMES THAT MEET THE SIX OBJECTIVES OF THE JOINT FIRE SCIENCE PROGRAM FOR FIRE SCIENCE EXCHANGE NETWORKS. NWFSCSPECIFIC OBJECTIVES AIM TO: 1) IMPROVE INFORMATION ACCESS, ACCURACY, AWARENESS, AND DELIVERY, 2) INCREASE INCLUSION, MULTI-WAY ENGAGEMENT, AND CO-PRODUCTION BETWEEN RESEARCH AND THE FIELD  AND 3) PROMOTE COLLABORATION AND CO-LEARNING THAT ADDRESSES INEQUITIES AND SUSTAINS AND CONSERVES RESILIENT SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS. WE WILL ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES THROUGH A ROBUST PARTNERSHIP OF CORE SCIENCE GENERATION AND DELIVERY ORGANIZATIONS IN THE NORTHWEST. OUTPUTS AND ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE UPDATING NWFSC GOVERNANCE, MAINTAINING AND GROWING PLATFORMS  NEEDS ASSESSMENTS INCLUSIVE OF UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, TRIBAL MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS  DISSEMINATING IDENTIFIED RESEARCH NEEDS  CONVENING A WESTSIDE FIRE KNOWLEDGE SUMMIT AND A MULTI-EXCHANGE WORKSHOP ON EQUITY ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE  SUPPORTING NATIONAL AND REGIONAL EVENTS AND CROSS-EXCHANGE LEARNING  AND DELIVERING SCIENCE APPLICATION BUNDLES THAT BRING TOGETHER MULTIPLE ACTIVITIES AND PLATFORMS ACROSS REGIONALLY-IMPORTANT THEMES.

FIRE IS A PERSISTENT THREAT TO BOTH HUMAN COMMUNITIES AND NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS AND A CRITICAL LAND MANAGEMENT CHALLENGE IN HAWAII AND THE US-AFFILIATED PACIFIC ISLANDS INCLUDING GUAM, CNMI, PALAU, AND YAP (IN THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRONESIA), WHERE THE PERCENTAGE OF LAND AREA BURNED ANNUALLY OFTEN DRAMATICALLY EXCEEDS THAT OF STATES ON THE US CONTINENT. ACCORDING TO REGIONAL LAND AND FIRE MANAGERS, THERE IS A NEED FOR FIRERELATED INFORMATION FOR LOCAL MANAGEMENT, HAWAII-BASED, AND DIRECTLY RELATED TO MICRONESIA. THE REGIONS DIVERSE SOCIAL, ECOLOGICAL AND CLIMATIC CONDITIONS COMBINED WITH LIMITED INVESTMENT IN FIRE RESEARCH POINTS TO THE URGENCY AND VALUE OF LEARNING FROM PRACTITIONERS IN LAND CARE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONNECTING THEM WITH SCIENTISTS TO IDENTIFY KNOWLEDGE GAPS AND CO-DEVELOP SOLUTIONS FOR MORE FIRE-ADAPTED COMMUNITIES AND FIRE-RESILIENT LANDSCAPES. FIRST, WE WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON TOPICAL PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED BY OUR ADVISORS AND AUDIENCE INCLUDING: 1. REGIONAL FIRE HISTORIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS  2. AFTER-FIRE SCIENCE AND ACTION  AND 3. NEW   RELEVANT WILDFIRE RESEARCH AND TOOLS  DEVELOPED AND DELIVERED BY FACT SHEETS (1-3 PER TRACT) AND VIRTUAL WORKSHOPS WEBINARS (1-2 PER TRACT), AS WELL AS IN-PERSON EVENTS AS COVID-RESTRICTIONS RELAX. FINALLY, THE PFX LEADERSHIP WILL PRIORITIZE EFFORTS TO INCREASE ENGAGEMENT WITH ACADEMICS AND STUDENTS, ESPECIALLY IN FIELDS UNDERREPRESENTED IN PACIFIC ISLAND FIRE SCIENCE, WITH THE SHORT-TERM GOAL OF INCREASING AWARENESS OF SCIENCE NEEDS AND PROJECT PARTNERS AND MEDIUM-TERM GOALS OF INCREASING FIRE-RELATED PROJECTS IN THE REGION

DETAILEDOBJECTIVES, OUTCOMES, AND METRICS FOR EVALUATION ARE OUTLINED IN OUR LOGIC MODEL. OBJECTIVES THIS PROJECT USES AN INTERDISCIPLINARY FRAMEWORK AND SURVEY BASED METHODS TO ASSESS LANDOWNER KNOWLEDGE AND DEMAND FOR PRESCRIBED FIRE PROGRAMS AND POLICIES THAT IMPACT BURNING ON PRIVATE LANDS. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT LANDOWNER INTEREST AND WILLINGNESS TO PAY FOR BURNING IS A FUNCTION OF TRADEOFFS IN RISK AND BENEFITS AND THE TYPES OF RESOURCES AND ASSISTANCE MADE AVAILABLE TO OWNERS. DATA TYPES INCLUDE KNOWLEDGE ASSESSMENTS, PSYCHOLOGICAL MEASURES, AND ECONOMIC MEASURES OF CHOICE (I.E., PREFERENCES, WILLINGNESS TO PAY). CASE STUDIES OF LANDOWNER EXPERIENCES WILL ALSO BE BUILT TO FACILITATE INFORMATION TRANSFER ACROSS PEERS.3. BENEFITSTHE DESIGN OF THIS PROJECT ALLOWS FOR THE TARGETED APPLICATION OF BOTH EDUCATION AND ECONOMIC INTERVENTIONS ACROSS DIFFERENT CATEGORIES OF LANDOWNERS IN DIFFERENT REGIONS OF CALIFORNIA. UNDERSTANDING THE PSYCHOLOGICAL SCHEMA OF LANDOWNERS WHO BURN (I.E., KNOWLEDGE, PERCEPTIONS ATTITUDES AND PERCEIVED SOCIAL NORMS) CAN HELP GUIDE EDUCATIONAL INTERVENTIONS TO SUPPORT MORE RESILIENCE OUTCOMES. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF UTILITY, OR THE VALUE, OF PRESCRIBED FIRE BENEFITS TO LANDOWNERS AND THEIR PREFERENCES FOR SUPPORT (E.G., PBA S, LIABILITY LAWS) CAN ELUCIDATE CONTEXTS IN WHICH LANDOWNERS ARE WILLING TO ASSUME THE COSTS OF BURNING, COMPARED TO CONTEXTS WHERE COST SHARE MAY NEED TO BE USED. MOREOVER, ECONOMIC VALUES IN THE FORM OF PREDICTED CONSUMER DEMAND CAN BE USED TO DIRECT THE EXPANSION OF PROGRAMS AND CONSULTANT SERVICES THAT SUPPORT PRIVATE LANDS BURNING. THE ECONOMIC ASPECT OF THIS PROJECT IS PARTICULARLY NOVEL SINCE THE PI, MELISSA KREYE, IS ONE OF THE FEW SOCIAL SCIENTISTS USING STATED PREFERENCE METHODS IN THE CONTEXT OF PRESCRIBED FIRE. COMBINING THIS WORK WITH A SERIES OF CASE STUDIES ALSO PROVIDES A NICE COUNTERPART, BY OFFERING A MORE CONTEXTUALIZED UNDERSTANDING OF LANDOWNER BEHAVIOR WITHIN A BROADER PICTURE.

OBJECTIVES OUR INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH TEAM WILL INVESTIGATE HOW TO MOST EFFECTIVELY FOSTER RESILIENT RECOVERY FROM WILDFIRE ON NIPF. WE WILL EMPLOY SPATIAL ANALYSES AND QUALITATIVE RESEARCH IN FIVE HYDROLOGICAL BASINS IN WESTERN OREGON THAT BURNED IN THE 2020 LABOR DAY FIRES TO 1. IDENTIFY, CHARACTERIZE, AND ASSESS THE CURRENT SOCIAL LANDSCAPE FOR WILDFIRE RECOVERY SUPPORT ON NIPF. WE WILL MAP LAND OWNERSHIPS, OUTLINE THE ADMINISTRATIVE REACH OF SUPPORT ORGANIZATIONS, AND IDENTIFY THESOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL FACTORS INFLUENCING THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESILIENCE IN RECOVERY ON NIPF.2. IDENTIFY, CHARACTERIZE, AND ASSESS THE ECOLOGICAL LANDSCAPE OF NONINDUSTRIAL PRIVATE FORESTLAND. WE WILL CATEGORIZE THE FACTORS INFLUENCING LANDOWNER DECISIONS TO REPLANT OR NOT TO REPLANT TREES, TRACK LAND COVER AND CANOPY CHANGES IN THE STUDY AREA, AND CO DESIGN REPLANTING PLANNING STRATEGIES FOR SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE.3. INFORM MORE RESPONSIVE AND FORWARD THINKING RECOVERY EFFORTSTHROUGH CO PRODUCED, TRANSFERABLE, AND ACTIONABLE RECOMMENDATIONS AND TOOLS. WE WILL ADVANCE THEORETICAL AND APPLIED UNDERSTANDINGS OF RED TAPE AND ADMINISTRATIVE BURDEN AND PRODUCE PRACTICAL RECOMMENDATIONS AND A TOOLBOX FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT, RECOVERY SUPPORT ORGANIZATIONS, AND NIPF OWNERS TO ENSURE OUR RESEARCH EFFORTS TRANSLATE INTO APPLIED SOLUTIONS FOR A VARIETY OF STAKEHOLDERS.3. BENEFITS THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO MORE EFFECTIVE DELIVERY OF POST FIRE RECOVERY SUPPORT THAT INCREASE NIPF RESILIENCE TO WILDFIRE. NIPF ARE A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF THE LANDSCAPE MATRIX IN COMMUNITIES ADJACENT TO WILDLANDS, AND IMPROVED EFFICIENCIES AND STREAMLINED IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST PRACTICES FOR WILDFIRE RESPONSE ON NIPF WILL RESULT IN CASCADING BENEFITSTHAT FACILITATE MORE ROBUST AND LONG TERM COMMUNITY LEVEL RESILIENCE TO WILDFIRE. PROJECT RESULTS WILL INCREASE EFFICIENCIES FOR ORGANIZATIONS AND AGENCIES DELIVERING RECOVERY SUPPORT TO NIPF OWNERS AND DEVELOP ACTIONABLE BEST PRACTICES FOR INCREASING WILDFIRE RESILIENCE ON NIPF AND IN SURROUNDING MATRIXED LANDS.

OBJECTIVES  TO UNDERSTAND THESE CONDITIONS, WE PROPOSE THREE TASKS  1) QUANTIFY POST FIRE RECOVERY OF VEGETATION AND THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT IN FIRE IMPACTED WUI COMMUNITIES, 2) IDENTIFY THE INDICATORS THAT CHARACTERIZE SOCIO ECOLOGICAL BUILT RECOVERY, AND 3) EXAMINE THE ECOLOGICAL, BUILT, AND SOCIO ECONOMIC TRADE OFFS BETWEEN POST FIRE RECOVERY TRAJECTORIES OF PERSISTENCE, ADAPTATION, AND TRANSFORMATION. WE HYPOTHESIZE  1) THAT SOME SOCIAL COMMUNITY CHARACTERISTICS MUST BE MAINTAINED TO ALLOW OTHER SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS TO ADAPT AND TRANSFORM. THESE CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDE TANGIBLE AND INTANGIBLE COMMUNITY RESOURCES THAT SUSTAIN COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDE THE GLUEFOR THEM TO RECOVER FROM WILDFIRES  AND 2) THAT ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS OF WUI COMMUNITIES PARTICULARLY FIRE FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY  INFLUENCE HOW SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS OPERATE AFTER A FIRE EVENT AND INFLUENCE LONG TERM RECOVERY. BY INVESTIGATING HOW SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS INTERACT WITH ECOLOGICAL FIRE CONDITIONS AND OWNERSHIP PATTERNS, WE WILL GAIN INSIGHTS ON WHAT RESOURCES ARE NEEDED TO FACILITATE TRANSFORMATIVE RECOVERY WHILE MAINTAINING KEY SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS.BENEFITS  A PRIMARY BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE A COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNITY RESILIENCE TRAJECTORY SELF ASSESSMENT GUIDE AND LEARNING TOOL MADE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH AN EXISTING WEB BASED PLATFORM DESIGNED TO HELP WUI COMMUNITY DECISION MAKERS, PLANNERS, RESIDENTS, LAND MANAGERS AND OTHERS VISUALIZE ECOLOGICAL, BUILT, AND SOCIO ECONOMIC INDICATORSOF THE RESILIENCE TRAJECTORIES. WUI COMMUNITY DECISION MAKERS AND MEMBERS WILL THEN BE ABLE TO SELF ASSESS WHAT INDICATORS ARE PREVALENT IN THEIR COMMUNITY. THE SELF ASSESSMENT CAN BE SHARED WITH OTHERS IN THE COMMUNITY TO FACILITATE DISCUSSION OF WHAT INDICATORS ARE IMPORTANT AND HOW TO ACHIEVE THEM. ADDITIONAL OUTPUTS WILL INCLUDE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS IN THE NATURAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCES, WEBINARS, AND WORKSHOPS WITH FIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES.

WE HAVE ORGANIZED OUR WORK AROUND SIX OBJECTIVES. FIRST, WE PLAN TO USE A NEEDS ASSESSMENT TO FORM RELATIONSHIPS WITH CASE STUDY INFORMANTS SPANNING THESE HUMAN COMMUNITIES, TO UNDERSTAND ELEMENTS OF ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIAL SYSTEMS RELEVANT TO THEIR RECOVERY PLANS. SECOND, WE WILL INTEGRATE THE LEARNING FROM THIS NEEDS ASSESSMENT TO DEVELOP INITIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE MAPS FOR EACH CASE STUDY. THOSE MAPS WILL SERVE AS CONTEXT FOR OUR THIRD OBJECTIVE, WHICH IS TO CONDUCT SEMI STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS EXPLORING STRUGGLES AND SUCCESSES IN EACH CASE STUDY. FOURTH, WE PLAN TO CONVENE FOCUS GROUPS OF DECISION MAKERS IN EACH CASE STUDY TO EXAMINE SCENARIOS OF RECOVERY, ASSESSING THE INFLUENCE OF ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIAL DRIVERS ON RECOVERY TRAJECTORIES. FIFTH, WE WILL GENERATE COUPLED SYSTEMS COMMUNITY RESILIENCE MAPS WEIGHTING THESE DRIVERS, SO THAT WE CAN USE SENSITIVITYANALYSES TO IDENTIFY AREAS OF INTERVENTION. RESULTING MAPS CAN ASSIST DECISION MAKING BY IDENTIFYING AREAS OF INFLUENCE IN VARIOUS MANAGEMENT SCENARIOS. FINALLY, OUR SIXTH OBJECTIVE IS TO CONDUCT A RESULTS DELIVERY WORKSHOP AND WEBINAR TO EXTEND THE REACHOF OUR FINDINGS BEYOND OUR CASE STUDIES.3. THIS WORK WILL ASSIST DECISION MAKERS IN MANAGING FOR RESILIENCE BY PROVIDING TO THEM INFORMATION ABOUT SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL FACTORS RELEVANT TO RECOVERY AS WELL AS SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF THOSE FACTORS AND WEIGHTED MAPS THAT CAN BE MANIPULATED BY MANAGERS TO VISUALIZE THE EFFECT ON RESILIENCE OF VARIOUS SCENARIOS. SINCE OUR WORK SPANS A DIVERSITY OF ECOSYSTEMS AND A RANGE OF TIME SINCE FIRE, IT WILL SUPPORT MANAGERS BEYOND THOSE CASE STUDY SYSTEMS IN IDENTIFYING THOSE SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL FACTORS THAT MAY BE AREAS OF INTERVENTION IN THEIR OWN SYSTEMS.

INCREASING WILDFIRE IMPACTS ACROSS DIVERSE SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES NECESSITATE AN EXPANDED FOCUS ON THE WAYS THAT RECOVERY PROCESSES INFLUENCE MORE SUSTAINABLE RELATIONSHIPS WITH WILDFIRE. TOOLS, RESOURCES AND BEST PRACTICES FOR APPROACHING RECOVERY PROCESSES THAT RESPOND TO LOCAL IMPACTS ARE NEEDED, YET THERE HAS BEEN LESS SYSTEMATIC RESEARCH INTO THE WAYS THAT POPULATIONS APPROACH, PRIORITIZE OR ACCESS RECOVERY RESOURCES IN RESPONSE TO CONTEXT SPECIFIC IMPACTS FROM WILDFIRE EVENTS. EFFORTS TO COMPILE, SYNTHESIZE, AND UNDERSTAND PATTERNS IN WILDFIRE RECOVERY PROCESSES ACROSS SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS ARE NECESSARY TO DETERMINE WHETHER AND HOW CURRENT RECOVERY GUIDANCE OR ASSISTANCE WILL ADVANCE DIVERSE COMMUNITIESNEED TO BETTER COEXIST WITH WILDFIRE. LESSONS AGGREGATED ACROSS CONDITIONS, AND AUGMENTED BY CASE STUDIES OF CONTEXT SPECIFIC WILDFIRE RECOVERY PROCESSES, ALSO HAVE THE CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS OR EVALUATE BEST PRACTICES FOR ADDRESSING A WIDE RANGE OF RECOVERY NEEDS THROUGH IMPROVED MONITORING. THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES THESE CRITICAL NEEDS, AS IDENTIFIED THROUGH OUR RECENT RESEARCH, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND WILDFIRE IMPACTS, RECOVERY NEEDS, AND USES OF RECOVERY ASSISTANCE ACROSS DIVERSE SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS.OBJECTIVES  WE WILL HELP COMPILE, ANALYZE AND SYNTHESIZE INFORMATION SURROUNDING WILDFIRE RECOVERY ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TO IMPROVE THE EFFICIENCY OF RECOVERY PLANNING OR MOBILIZATION. WE ALSO WILL DRAW GENERALIZABLE LESSONS, PATTERNS AND IN DEPTH BEST PRACTICES SURROUNDING RECOVERY THROUGH ANALYSIS OF EXISTING EFFORTS AT PROGRESSIVELY NESTED SCALES (E.G., REGIONALLY, STATEWIDE, ACROSS COMMUNITIES). OUR APPLICATION OF BOTH SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL APPROACHES WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES OBJ.  1  ASSEMBLE AN OPEN ACCESS DATABASE OF AVAILABLE RECOVERY ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR WILDFIRE RECOVERYOBJ.  2  DETERMINE AVAILABILITY AND USE OF EXISTING ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS ACROSS SOCIALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY DIVERSE WILDFIRE EVENTSOBJ.  3  EXPLORE IN DEPTH LESSONSSURROUNDING RECOVERY PROCESSES ACROSS SOCIALLY DIVERSE POPULATIONS.

THERE IS A NEED TO UNDERSTAND HOW FIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES RECOVER AND HOW RECOVERY CAN CONTRIBUTE TO SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE, ESPECIALLY BECAUSE WILDFIRE RECOVERY MAY REPRESENT AN OPPORTUNITY FOR BUILDING TRANSFORMATIVE RESILIENCE ON THE LANDSCAPE. WE WILL PARTNER WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS IN WILDFIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES TO GENERATE INFORMATION THAT IS RELEVANT TO THEM AS THEY BUILD BACK THEIR COMMUNITIES. WE SEEK TO IDENTIFY HOW RESIDENTS VIEW COMMUNITY RECOVERY AND RESILIENCE, WHO IS WORKING ON RECOVERY EFFORTS, AND HOW RESOURCES ARE DISTRIBUTED, AS WELL AS GAPS IN RESOURCE AVAILABILITY. WE WILL DEVELOP A MODEL OF SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE IN WILDFIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES THAT CAN INFORM RECOVERY IN COMMUNITIES BEYOND OUR CASE STUDY LOCATIONS.OBJECTIVE 1  BUILD UPON AND EXPAND WORKING RELATIONSHIPS WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES THROUGH ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS.OBJECTIVE 2  CHARACTERIZE HOW COMMUNITY MEMBERS VIEW RECOVERY AND SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE, AND HOW THEY ASSESS PROGRESS MADE TOWARD RECOVERY.OBJECTIVE 3  ASSESS THE EQUITY ISSUES OF COMMUNITY RECOVERY IN FIRE ADAPTED LANDSCAPES, INCLUDING WHO IS IMPACTED BY PAST FIRES, WHO IS INVOLVED IN RECOVERY, WHO BENEFITS FROM RECOVERY EFFORTS, AND WHO HAS OR DOES NOT HAVE POWER IN THE PROCESS OF BUILDING ADAPTIVE CAPACITY AND SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE.OBJECTIVE 4  DESCRIBE THE FORMAL AND INFORMAL SOCIAL NETWORKS, INCLUDING LOCAL TO FEDERAL ORGANIZATIONS, WORKING TOWARD RECOVERY AND BUILDING SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE, HOW THEY INTERACT, AND HOW THEY IMPACT COMMUNITY RECOVERY EFFORTS.OBJECTIVE 5  DESCRIBE THE RESOURCES  FINANCIAL, SOCIAL, AND HUMAN AVAILABLE TO FACILITATE COMMUNITY RECOVERY, AS WELL AS GAPS IN AVAILABLE AND ACCESSIBLE RESOURCES.OBJECTIVE 6  BUILD UPON AND REFINE EXISTING MODELS OF COMMUNITYRECOVERY TO CLARIFY WHAT IS HELPFUL FOR THESE COMMUNITIES AND OTHERS IN BUILDING SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE IN FIRE PRONE LANDSCAPES.OUR PRIMARY AUDIENCE WILL BE WILDFIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES. CASE STUDY COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BE TARGETED THROUGH COMMUNITY FORUMS, A PUBLIC FACING WEBSITE, AND DISSEMINATION OF A SCIENCE BRIEF. OTHER COMMUNITIES WILL BE TARGETED THROUGH THE SCIENCE BRIEF AND PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS. FOR POLICY MAKERS AND AGENCIES, WE WILL DEVELOP A WHITE PAPER THAT CAN INFORM HOW TO MEET THE NEEDS OF FIRE IMPACTED COMMUNITIES. FOR ACADEMICS, WE WILL COMMUNICATE FINDINGS THROUGH TWO MASTERS THESES, TWO PEER REVIEWED MANUSCRIPTS, AND FOUR CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS. WE WILL ALSO DISTRIBUTE FINDINGS THROUGH THE NEWLY FORMED HUMBOLDTSTATE UNIVERSITY FIRE RESILIENCE INSTITUTE, WHICH IS WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA AND SOUTHERN OREGON REGION, AND THROUGH THE CALIFORNIA AND PACIFIC NORTHWEST FIRE SCIENCE CONSORTIUMS.

QUANTIFY LEGACY TREE MORTALITY AT THE STAND SCALE IN PREVIOUSLY PRESCRIBED BURNED AREAS.I WILL QUANTIFY FIRE RELATED MORTALITY OF HARDWOOD TREES OF ALL THREE SPECIES (E25 CM DIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT  DBH ) IN AN EQUAL NUMBER OF BURNED AND UNBURNED UNITS. MORTALITY DUE TO PRESCRIBED FIRE TREATMENT WILL BE ANALYZED, AS WELL AS STAND LEVEL FACTORS SUCH AS COMPETITION, COMPOSITION, AND TOPOGRAPHY. BASED ON FIELD OBSERVATIONS, IT IS SUSPECTED THAT RECENT LEGACY HARDWOOD MORTALITY WILL BE HIGHER IN UNITS TREATED BY PRESCRIBED FIRE THAN IN UNBURNED UNITS. IT IS ALSO HYPOTHESIZED THAT COMPETITION WILL BE POSITIVELY CORRELATED WITH MORTALITY, AND BLACK OAKS WILL HAVE HIGHEST RATES WHILE TANOAKS HAVE LOWEST OBSERVABLE RATES OF MORTALITY.DETERMINE THE ROLE OF FIRE SCAR AND CAVITY CHARACTERISTICS ASSOCIATED WITH LEGACY TREE MORTALITY.AMONG DEAD LEGACY HARDWOOD TREES IN PREVIOUS BURN UNITS, MORTALITY WILL BE ANALYZED AT THE TREE LEVEL ACCORDING TO FACTORS SUCH AS SCAR VOLUME, TREE SPECIES, SIZE (DBH), COMPETITION (TOTAL AND DOUGLAS FIR), AND FIRE DAMAGE (BOLE CHAR). I HYPOTHESIZE THAT LARGER FIRE SCARS, SMALLER TREE SIZE, GREATER COMPETITION, AND FIRE DAMAGE WILL BE MORE POSITIVELY ASSOCIATED WITH MORTALITY FOLLOWING PRESCRIBED FIRE. I WILL PROVIDE THE KARUK TRIBE, COOPERATING AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITY WITH AN OVERVIEW OF FINDINGS OF LEGACY HARDWOOD FIRE MORTALITY, IN THE FORM OF LOCAL PRESENTATIONS AND MANAGEMENT BRIEF, TO SUPPORT LEGACY HARDWOOD RETENTION. THIS RESEARCH WILL ADVANCE CALIFORNIA HARDWOOD FOCUSED SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH RELATED TO FIRE INDUCED MORTALITY, SPECIFICALLY RELATED TO FIRE SCARS AND CAVITIES DEVELOPED DURING AN ERA OF INDIGENOUS MANAGEMENT WHEN FIRE WAS FREQUENT. THIS PROJECT ADDITIONALLY ENGAGES THE KARUK COMMUNITY IN ETHICAL KNOWLEDGE BUILDING BY PROVIDING COMPENSATION FOR KARUK CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS TO BUILD K 12 CURRICULUM MATERIALS TO ENSURE LOCALIZED AND APPROPRIATE INTERGENERATIONAL LEARNING AMONG NATIVE YOUTH REGARDING VALUED LEGACY HARDWOOD TREES.

THROUGH A COLLABORATION WITH TNC, MY OBJECTIVE IS TO EXAMINE THE SHORT TERM EFFECT OF WINTER PRESCRIBED BURNING OF FOREST STANDS ON LABO AND LASE FORAGING ACTIVITY AND CONTRAST WITH THE ACTIVITY OF THESE SPECIES PRE BURN AND IN UNBURNED STANDS. I WILL USE ACOUSTIC RECORDING OF BAT ECHOLOCATION CALL SEQUENCES TO EXAMINE BAT ACTIVITY THROUGH A PRE POST TREATMENT CONTROL EXPERIMENT IN FOREST STANDS SUBJECT TO WINTER PRESCRIBED BURNING (I.E., DECEMBER  MARCH).THIS IS A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT WITH CAFMS AND SBRFLN PARTNERS, INCLUDING USDA FOREST SERVICE, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, AND NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION. IT WILL SUPPORT PLACE BASED ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AND FURTHER THE JOINT FIRE SCIENCE PROGRAMS COMMITMENT TO SOUND SCIENTIFIC STUDIES THAT SUPPORT LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND COLLABORATIVELY ADDRESS ISSUES IN WILDLAND FIRE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT. UNDERSTANDING WINTER HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF LABO AND LASE IN THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS WILL ALLOW REGIONAL AGENCIES TO ADAPT WINTER AND SPRING BURNING TO MEET THE SPECIES NEEDS. RESULTS AND PRODUCTS WILL BE EXCHANGED WITH CAMFS AND SBRFLN PARTNERS THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT PERIOD, AND CAFMS WILL COMMIT TO ONE FACT SHEET THAT SUMMARIZES THE RESEARCH. I WILL WORK WITH THESE COLLABORATORS TO ACCELERATE THE AWARENESS, UNDERSTANDING, AND ADOPTION OF THIS FIRE SCIENCE INFORMATION BY THE PARTNER LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES THROUGH A VARIETY OF DELIVERABLES INCLUDING REPORTS, FACT SHEETS, WEBINARS, PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND PRESENTATIONS AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL MEETINGS.

BUILDING OFF OF AN APPROVED DISSERTATION PROJECT FOCUSED ON THE LONGEVITY OF COMBINED FUEL TREATMENTS (THINNING, MASTICATION, PRESCRIBED BURNING, AND GRAZING), THIS PROPOSAL WILL  1) DETERMINE IF THE EFFECTS OF FUEL TREATMENTS DIFFER IN REGARD TO PLANT AVAILABLE N AND POST FIRE VEGETATION RECOVERY  AND 2) WILL ASSESS NUTRITIONAL QUALITY OF THREE PROLIFIC WESTERN U.S. DECIDUOUS SHRUB SPECIES TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BROWSING GOATS AS A FIRE MANAGEMENT TOOL ACROSS SEASONS.FOR GOATS TO BE MOST EFFECTIVE, MANAGERS NEED MORE INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGICAL EFFECTS AND ON THE PROTEIN CONTENT AND DIGESTIBILITY OF COMMON SHRUBS IN THE NORTHERN ROCKIES OVER THE COURSE OF THE GROWING SEASON. UNDERSTANDING THE SEASONAL DIGESTIBILITY OF AVAILABLE FORAGE WILL PROVIDE MANAGERS WITH THE TOOLS TO MATCH GOAT MAINTENANCE ENERGY NEEDS WITH THE APPROPRIATE FORAGES AND SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING PROGRAMS WHILE PURSUING FUEL MANAGEMENT TREATMENTS. THIS INFORMATION IS NEEDED SO THAT GOAT BROWSING CAN BEAN EFFECTIVE TOOL FOR REDUCING LIVE WOODY FUELS WHILE ALSO MAINTAINING THE NUTRITIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE ANIMAL. RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED TO MANAGERS IN A VARIETY OF FORMATS, INCLUDING FIELD TOURS, WEBINARS AND PUBLICATIONS.

OUR PROPOSED PROJECT EXAMINES SEVERAL 2020 WILDFIRES ACROSS THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS BY COLLECTING SOIL FOR FUNGAL SEQUENCING AND MEASURING ABOVE GROUND REVEGETATION ON SAMPLE SITES STRATIFIED BY FIRE SEVERITY. DEDUCING THE EFFECTS OF FIRE ALTERED FUNGAL COMMUNITIES ON FOREST REGENERATION WILL REQUIRE BOTH SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL ANALYSES. BY EXPANDING UPON PREVIOUS WORK, OUR PROPOSAL SEEKS TO  1) FULLY UTILIZE LARGE BURN SCAR ELEVATIONAL GRADIENTS BY INCLUDING A LOW ELEVATION FOREST TYPE (DOMINATED BY PINUS PONDEROSA) IN OUR SPATIAL ANALYSES OF POST FIRE FUNGAL PLANT RELATIONSHIPS, 2) EXPAND FUNGAL FUNCTIONAL GROUPS, GUILDS, AND SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN POST FIRE ENVIRONMENTS BY EXPLICITLY TARGETING RHIZOSPHERIC FUNGI AND COMPARING RESULTS WITH BULK SOIL COLLECTION, AND 3) EXAMINE TEMPORAL VARIATIONS IN FUNGAL AND PLANT REGENERATION BY SAMPLING IN A SECOND YEAR POST FIRE. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT, IN ADDITION TO THE IMPACT OF FIRE SEVERITY, THE DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE OF FUNGAL AND PLANT REGENERATION WILL RELY HEAVILY ON FOREST TYPE, SAMPLE MICROSITE LOCATION, AND TIME SINCE FIRE. WE WILL DISSEMINATE INFORMATION THROUGH A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION, PRESENT AT ONE OR MORE NATIONAL OR INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES, AND INCLUDE THIS WORK AS A CHAPTER OF AN MS THESIS. FURTHER, WE WILL DO A WEBINAR AND TWO PAGE RESEARCH BRIEF FOR SRFSN.OUR STUDY TAKES AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO CONSIDERING THE EFFECTS OF CHANGING WILDFIRE PATTERNS ON FOREST ECOSYSTEM SUCCESSION AT BOTH BELOW AND ABOVE GROUND SCALES. THUS, IT WILL PROVIDE NEW PERSPECTIVES ON COMMUNITY SUCCESSION AND SUPPLEMENT STUDIES ON THE EFFECTS OF CURRENT AND FUTURE FIRE BEHAVIOR. STUDYING THE INTERSECTION OF POST FIRE FUNGAL REGENERATION AND PLANT SUCCESSION IS CRITICAL TO AN EXPANDED VIEW OF FOREST COMMUNITY RESPONSE, WHICH WILLAID LAND MANAGERS IN DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE RECOVERY PLANS IN BURNED AREAS. WE HOPE THAT RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL ADVANCE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW IMPERATIVE POST FIRE SOIL CONDITIONS ARE FOR FOREST REGENERATION AND IMPROVE LAND MANAGERSABILITY TO BUILD RESILIENCE OF FORESTED ECOSYSTEMS AFTER WILDFIRE

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ADDRESS KEY UNCERTAINTIES IN HOW CLIMATE AND WILDFIRE INTERACT TO INFLUENCE WESTERN LARCH RECRUITMENT. THIS WORK BUILDS OFF THE CURRENT MS RESEARCH OF STUDENT INVESTIGATOR VIEIRA, FUNDED BY THE USGS NORTH CENTRAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER (NC CASC), WHICH AIMS TO QUANTIFY HOW CLIMATE IMPACTS POST FIRE WESTERN LARCH RECRUITMENT SPECIFICALLY ACROSS THE WARMEST, DRIEST PORTIONS OF ITS RANGE (13). OVER THE SUMMER OF 2021 VIEIRA SAMPLED 33 SITES FOR THIS WORK. TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE THE INTERACTING IMPACTS OF CLIMATE AND WILDFIRE ON WESTERN LARCH REGENERATION, THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL ADD 30 40 PLOTS WITHIN THE COOL, WET PORTION OF ITS RANGE, EXTENDING THE SCOPE OF ONGOING WORK TO ADDRESS BOTH POTENTIAL RANGE CONTRACTION (ALONG THE WARM, DRY EDGE) AND RANGE EXPANSION (ALONG THE COOL, WET EDGE). SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ANSWER THREE QUESTIONS  (1) HOW DO SEASONAL TO ANNUAL CLIMATE CONDITIONS IMPACT POST FIRE WESTERN LARCH REGENERATION IN THE COOL WET PORTION OF ITS RANGE  (2) HOW DOES FIRE SEVERITY INTERACT WITH CLIMATE TO IMPACT POST FIRE WESTERN LARCH REGENERATION IN THE COOL WET PORTION OF ITS RANGE  (3) HOW DOES THE CLIMATE SUITABILITY FOR POST FIRE WESTERN LARCH REGENERATION CHANGE UNDER VARYING SCENARIOS OF FUTURE CLIMATE 3. BENEFITSTHE PROPOSED WORK WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATE RECRUITMENT RELATIONSHIPS FOR WESTERN LARCH IN THE POST FIRE CONTEXT. THIS WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT GOALS FOCUSED ON LANDSCAPE RESILIENCE TO FIRE UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING POST FIRE REFORESTATION. THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH USFS REGION 1 SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS, OUR RESULTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVEMENT OF A REFORESTATION TOOL USED TO PRIORITIZE POST FIRE PLANTING EFFORTS. WE WILL COMMUNICATE FINDINGS TO THE SCIENTIFIC AND FOREST MANAGEMENT COMMUNITIES VIA A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION, A RESEARCH BRIEF, A WEBINAR, AND THROUGH SITE VISITS.

THIS RESEARCH ON FIRE EFFECTS AND POST FIRE COMMUNITY RECOVERY WILL HELP INFORM FUELS AND PRESCRIBED FIRE MANAGEMENT IN A CHANGING CLIMATE AND FIRE ENVIRONMENT. USING THREE COMPLEMENTARY STUDIES, THIS RESEARCH ASKS  1) IS SEED SURVIVAL AFFECTED BY FIRE INTENSITY ARISING FROM LAND USE AND FIRE REGIME HISTORY  2) DO LAND USE AND FIRE REGIME HISTORY AFFECT PATHOGEN ATTACK OF SEEDS ON THE FOREST FLOOR  AND, 3) HOW WILL CLIMATE CHANGE (EXTREME PRECIPITATION) AND FIRE HISTORY AFFECT SEED SURVIVAL  THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE AT LEAST TWO PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS THAT EXAMINE THE INTERACTION BETWEEN FIRE REGIMES AND EXTREME PRECIPITATION EVENTS ON SEED SURVIVAL AND THE ROLE THAT FOREST FLOOR DEPTH (LITTER AND DUFF) AFFECTS RESTORATION BY SEED IN THE CONTEXT OF VARIABLE FIRE REGIMES. RESULTS WILL ALSO BE DISSEMINATED AT LOCAL AND REGIONAL CONFERENCES SUCH AS THE ANNUAL MIDWEST ECOLOGY AND EVOLUTION CONFERENCE AND ECOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA CONFERENCE. AND, WE WILL COMMUNICATE OUR FINDINGS DIRECTLY TO MANAGERS THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AND RESEARCH BRIEFS PUBLISHED WITH THE JOINT FIRE SCIENCE EXCHANGE NETWORK.THE RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT OF LONGLEAF PINE FOREST STRUCTURE AND THE USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE UNDER CHANGING CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. A GUIDE FOR BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO INCREASE THE SUCCESS OF SEED ADDITIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF PRESCRIBED FIRE AND LITTER AND DUFF DEPTH MANAGEMENT WILL BE CREATED USING THE RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT. RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL BE PRESENTED TO MANAGERS AT THE USFS SRS AND MORE BROADLY AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES. RESEARCH BRIEFS WILL ALSO BE PREPARED AND DISSEMINATED THROUGH THE JOINT FIRE SCIENCE EXCHANGE NETWORK AND THE US FOREST SERVICE SAVANNAH RIVER.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE MODEL DERIVED PROJECTION PRODUCTS BY INCREASING THE HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION USING VARIABLE RESOLUTION CLIMATE MODELS TO ASSESS IMPACTS OF LOCAL CONDITIONS (E.G., ELEVATION, CLIMATE CLASSIFICATION, OR FUELS). AND WILL ASSESS UNCERTAINTIES IN SUB GRID SCALE PRECIPITATION MODELS AND IDENTIFY IMPACTS ON WILDFIRE PROJECTIONS.THE PROPOSAL WILL COMPLETE ESSENTIAL RESEARCH IN TERMS OF FINDING OPTIMAL HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION FOR FUTURE MODELING EXPERIMENTS.COMPLETE HIGH RESOLUTION CLIMATE PROJECTION DATA FOR THE WESTERN US FOCUSED ON FIRE MANAGEMENT.AND PRESENT AN UNIQUE ASSESSMENT OF THE SENSITIVITY TO DIFFERENT PRECIPITATION PARAMETERIZATION SCHEMES FOR THE FUTURE PROJECTIONS OF AREA BURNED.

WE PROPOSE TO ESTABLISH LONG TERM MONITORING OF THE EFFECTS OF THE REINTRODUCTION OF FIRE IN A LONG UNBURNED MIXED OAK SHORTLEAF PINE FOREST. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO QUANTIFY AND COMPARE FUEL LOADING, FUELBED COMPOSITION, AND SPATIAL PATTERNS OF WOODY PLANTS IN BURNED VS. UNBURNED PLOTS IN A MATURE MIXED OAK SHORTLEAFPINE FOREST. ADDITIONAL SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS OF FUEL LOADING AND FUELBED COMPOSITION WILL SUPPLEMENT THE ONGOING DISSERTATION RESEARCH, RESULTING IN A MORE COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF MIXED OAK SHORTLEAF PINE FOREST DEVELOPMENT.PRESCRIBED FIRE MAY BE UNINTENTIONALLY APPLIED WITHOUT CLEARLY DEFINED OBJECTIVES OR CONSIDERATION OF LONG TERM ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCES. RESULTS FROM THIS PROPOSED STUDY WILL INFORM FOREST MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS ON THE ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS AND OR CONSEQUENCES OF THE REINTRODUCTION OF FIRE IN MIXEDWOOD STANDS AT A BROAD RANGE OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. PRESCRIBED FIRE SCIENCE LAGS BEHIND WILDFIRE SCIENCE, THEREFORE QUANTITATIVE EMPIRICAL STUDIES OF PRESCRIBED FIRE EFFECTS ARE URGENTLY NEEDED.

OUR PROPOSED STUDY WOULD INVESTIGATE TWO ASPECTS OF FUEL TREATMENT CONFIGURATION EFFECTS ON BIRD COMMUNITIES, USING A SPATIALLY EXPLICIT LANDSCAPE ECOLOGY FRAMEWORK. WE WILLTEST THE EFFECTS OF THIN TREATMENTS FOLLOWED BY PRESCRIBED FIRE, BECAUSE THIS TREATMENT TYPE HAS OFTEN BEENSHOWN TO BE HIGHLY EFFECTIVE AT REDUCING FUEL LOADS. OUR STUDY QUESTIONS ARE  HOW DOES BIRD COMMUNITY DIVERSITY AND INDIVIDUAL SPECIES ABUNDANCE RESPOND TO TWO KEY FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH LANDSCAPE FUEL TREATMENTS  1) PROXIMITY TO EDGE OF TREATMENT BOTH WITHIN AND OUTSIDE OF THE TREATMENT, AND 2) LANDSCAPE CONTEXT SURROUNDING THE TREATMENT FOREST MANAGERS ARE TASKED WITH MANAGING FOR MULTIPLE VALUES, AND IN DRY FORESTS OF THE WESTERN US THESE INCLUDE BOTH WILDFIRE HAZARD REDUCTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION. OUR STUDY WILL SUPPORT THE CAPACITY OF MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS TO ANTICIPATE THE EFFECT OF FUEL TREATMENT CONFIGURATION ON WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY, BY IMPROVING FINE SCALE UNDERSTANDING OF TREATMENT EDGE EFFECTS AND BROAD SCALE UNDERSTANDING OF LANDSCAPE CONTEXT EFFECTS. THESE INSIGHTS WILL HELP MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS DEVELOP METHODSFOR BALANCING MULTIPLE VALUES IN WESTERN DRY FORESTS, WHEN USED IN COMBINATION WITH THE GROWING BODY OF LITERATURE ON OPTIMIZING FUEL TREATMENT ROTATIONS AND CONFIGURATIONS FOR WILDFIRE HAZARD REDUCTION (FINNEY 2001, FINNEY ET AL. 2007, BAR MASSADA ET AL.2011, ALEXANDRE ET AL. 2016, AGER ET AL. 2017).A WEBINAR AND A RESEARCH BRIEF DETAILING THE RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED TO THE NORTHWEST FIRE SCIENCE CONSORTIUM. THIS STUDY WILL FORM A CHAPTER IN DON RADCLIFFES PHD DISSERTATION, AND WILL BE PUBLISHED IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL

THE 2 3 2 PARTNERSHIP AIMS TO ADDRESS FOREST HEALTH CONCERNS, MANAGE FIRE AND PROTECT WATERSHEDS THROUGH STRATEGIC COLLABORATIONS ACROSS COLORADO AND NEW MEXICOS PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS. THE RESEARCH QUESTIONS PRESENTED IN THE PROPOSAL BODY ARE DESIGNED TO MEET THE FOLLOWING THREE OBJECTIVES OBJ.1  EXAMINE HOW FIRE POLICY INFLUENCES THE FORMATION AND MISSION OF LAND MANAGEMENT COLLABORATIVESOBJ.2  EXAMINE HOW LAND MANAGEMENT PARTNERSHIPS INCORPORATE BASI INTO DECISION MAKING ABOUT WILDFIRE RISK REDUCTIONOBJ.3. DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR EFFECTIVE POLICY INTEGRATION AMONG BOUNDARY SPANNING PARTNERSHIPS OR COLLABORATIVE GROUPS ACROSS LANDSCAPE AND SUB LANDSCAPE SCALESI WILL USE SEMI STRUCTURED INTERVIEWS TO COLLECT QUALITATIVE DATA FROM 2 3 2 PARTNERSHIP MEMBERS. THIS RESEARCH WILL CULMINATE IN A PUBLISHED PAPER AND A SERIES OF RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE 2 3 2 PARTNERSHIP, AMONG OTHER OUTPUTS, WHICH WILL PROVIDE USEFUL AND HIGHLYTRANSFERABLE INSIGHTS TO OTHER COLLABORATIVES.UNDERSTANDING HOW COLLABORATIVE FIRE MANAGEMENT PARTNERSHIPS FUNCTION AT THE SCIENCE MANAGEMENT NEXUS IS CRITICAL FOR DESIGNING AND DISSEMINATING EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION ABOUT EMERGENT RESEARCH. FINDINGS FROM THIS STUDY CAN ALSO POINT TO BEST PRACTICES FOR TRANSLATING NATIONAL POLICY TO LOCAL CONTEXTS AND IDENTIFY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR DECISION MAKING AROUND BASI. IMPORTANTLY, THIS STUDY HAS IMPLICATIONS FOR MORE EFFECTIVE SCIENCE MANAGEMENT COMMUNICATIONS ANDPARTNERSHIPS THROUGH THE JFSP EXCHANGE NETWORK. THIS WILL HELP POLICYMAKERS UNDERSTAND HOW TO BETTER SUPPORT CROSS BOUNDARY FIRE MANAGEMENT AS MITIGATION, SUPPRESSION, AND RECOVERY BECOME INCREASINGLY SOCIALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY COMPLEX.

THE ABILITY TO CHARACTERIZE WILDLAND FUEL LOADING IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSING FIRE BEHAVIOR AND EFFECTS (SANDBERG ET AL. 2001). WITHIN SAGEBRUSH STEPPE PLANT COMMUNITIES, SHRUBS ARE THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF WOODY FUELS (BORNE AND BUNTING 2011). FURTHER, BIOMASS ESTIMATES ARE INFORMATIVE OUTSIDE OF INFORMING FUEL LOADING  THEY MAY ALSO INFORM PLANT COMMUNITY COMPETITION AND AVAILABLE BROWSE (RITTENHOUSE AND SNEVA 1977). TRADITIONAL TECHNIQUES TO ESTIMATE BIOMASS INVOLVES DESTRUCTIVE SAMPLING, WHICH IS TIME CONSUMING AND LABORIOUS, ESPECIALLY WHEN SHRUBS MUST BE DIVIDED INTO FUELS CLASSES (RITTENHOUSE AND SNEVA 1977). DESTRUCTIVE SAMPLING TECHNIQUES MAY NOT BE CONDUCIVE TO CERTAIN STUDY RECOMMENDATION FOR NEW AWARDVERSION 2 APRIL 4, 2022AREAS AND MONITORING PROJECTS WHICH REQUIRE INDIVIDUAL SHRUBS TO BE ASSESSED MULTIPLE TIMES. ALLOMETRIC BIOMASS AND LOADING EQUATIONS PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE METHOD TO CALCULATE SHRUB BIOMASS USING HEIGHT AND CANOPY SIZE MEASUREMENTS, WHICH SAVES TIME AND EFFORT IN FIELD DATA COLLECTION. THESE EQUATIONS CAN BOTH ACCURATELY REFLECT BIOMASS DUE TO SITE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND ARE USEFUL ACROSS A LARGE STUDY AREA. THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE SPECIES SPECIFIC ALLOMETRIC EQUATIONS FOR DOMINANT SHRUBS IN SAGEBRUSH PLANT COMMUNITIES, WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR ESTIMATION OF SHRUB FUEL LOADING BASED ON FIELD MEASUREMENTS OF SHRUB SIZE. FURTHER, THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS SUITABILITY OF USING IMAGERY CAPTURED WITH AN UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLE (UAV) TO GENERATE SHRUB VOLUME MEASUREMENTS AND ULTIMATELY BIOMASS AND FUEL LOADING.1. CREATE PREDICTIVE REGRESSION MODELS TO DETERMINE SITE AND SPECIES SPECIFIC SHRUB BIOMASS USING HEIGHT AND CROWN MEASUREMENT FROM EXISTING SAGESTEP DATA2. INDEPENDENTLY VALIDATE REGRESSION MODELS USING DOUBLE SAMPLING TECHNIQUE TO ASSESS MODEL FIT IN ALTERNATE SITES AND SPECIES3. ASSESS SUITABILITY OF SURVEYING SHRUB VOLUME USING AN UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLE (UAV) COMPARED TO IN SITU MEASUREMENTS FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND MONITORING EFFORTS

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO INVESTIGATE TO WHICH EXTENT VARIATIONS IN COMMUNITY LEVEL  FLAMMABILITY TRAITS CAN IMPACT FIRE BEHAVIOR IN PRESCRIBED FIRES IN TWO FIRE DEPENDENT FOREST TYPES   LONGLEAF PINE AND UPLAND OAK. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT FIRE SEVERITY, INTENSITY, AND RESIDENCE TIME MAY  BE PREDICTABLE BASED ON INDIVIDUAL SPECIES TRAITS, AND THAT INCREASED COMMUNITY LEVEL  FLAMMABILITY TRAITS WILL INCREASE FIRE BEHAVIOR METRICS DURING PRESCRIBED BURNS. WITH THIS RESEARCH,  WE EXPECT TO PROVIDE FIRE PRACTITIONERS INFORMATION THAT CAN SUPPORT THEIR ACTIVITY WHEN  PROSPECTING AREAS FOR FIRE PRESCRIPTION, BY BETTER EVALUATING THE FACTORS THAT CAN INFLUENCE FIRE  BEHAVIOR.ONE OF THE BENEFITS THIS RESEARCH CAN PROVIDE TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND THE PRESCRIBED FIRE  PRACTITIONERS IS THE POSSIBILITY OF BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE SPECIFICITY OF THE SYSTEMS THEY ARE  CONDUCTING PRESCRIBED FIRES. BY CONSIDERING THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE UNDERSTORY COMMUNITY AND  THE IMPORTANT SPECIES THAT COLONIZE THIS PORTION OF THE FOREST, THE DECISION MAKING PROCESS CAN BE  IMPROVED AND MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO MEET THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PRESCRIBED FIRES IN PROGRESS.  FURTHERMORE, THIS RESEARCH CAN PROVIDE SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION OF TARGET SPECIES THAT COULD AID  ON FIRE REINTRODUCTION IN FIRE SUPPRESSED AREAS. IT WOULD REPRESENT A RELEVANT CONTRIBUTION TO  RESEARCHERS, LANDOWNERS AND SCIENTISTS THAT ARE WORKING WITH THE MANAGEMENT ASPECT OF FIRE.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO DETERMINE HOW CHANGES IN CANOPY COVER AND  FUEL TYPES INFLUENCE TALLOW SEED VIABILITY AND GERMINATION RATES IN COASTAL PINE FLATWOODS  AND SAVANNAS OF THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. USING PLOT LEVEL EXPERIMENTAL BURNS THAT MIMIC  INCREASING TALLOW INVASION IMPACTS ON THE FUELBED. RECOMMENDATION FOR NEW AWARD VERSION 2 APRIL 4, 2022 THIS PROJECT WILL FOSTER A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF TRADE OFFS THAT MAY EXIST WHEN USING  PRESCRIBED FIRE IN BIOLOGICALLY INVADED COMMUNITIES. TALLOW IS A THREAT TO DIVERSE COASTAL  PINE FLATWOODS AND SAVANNAS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. RESULTS WILL IDENTIFY ECOLOGICAL  INTERACTIONS BETWEEN FIRE AND TALLOW THAT CAN BE USED TO CREATE NEW, EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT  STRATEGIES TO MINIMIZE THE SPREAD OF THIS INVASIVE SPECIES IN ENDANGERED ECOSYSTEMS   ADDITIONALLY, THIS STUDY WILL ADD INFORMATION ON TALLOW REGENERATION CHARACTERISTICS.
